Kenneth Lou, Co-founder at SeedlyLevel 8. WizardAnswered on 26 Oct 2018Save first... Get at least 6 months worth of rainy day funds, then invest the excess beyond that.Rainy day funds is basically 6 months worth of fixed expenses and necessities (eg rent, water, food, utilities, insurance premiums etc) Yup! So the steps would be: Save up enough that cover 6 months of your rainy day fundsInvest the balance beyond that by a Dollar cost average method (DCA)Or if you see that the market is down now, you can choose Lump Sum invest (LSI)And adopt this method you see here monthly: You can read more about this here: https://blog.seedly.sg/working-adults-allocate-your-monthly-salary/0 comments0
